bestBHT.bht: Recognize and honor the presbyters or bishops who labor among you, preside over you, and admonish you in the Lord. Appreciate their office, treat them with respect, and generously support their needs. They are called to put sense into the heads of the congregation, gently reminding and instructing them. Let these laborers in the word be abundantly honored for their work in the edification of the Church and the salvation of souls. They diligently study, pray, and preach to enlighten and align the hearts and minds of the people with God's will.

Henry Alford: to know: i.e. favourably and honourably to recognize.
The persons indicated by them which labour... preside... admonish..., are the same, viz. the presbyters or bishops.
in the Lord, as the element in which, the matter with regard to which, their presidency takes place: ‘in divine things.’
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Here, 'we beseech you,' as if it were a personal favor (Paul making the cause of the Thessalonian presbyters, as it were, his own).
Recognize their office, and treat them accordingly with reverence and with liberality in supplying their needs.
'Admonish you,' one of their leading functions; the Greek is 'put in mind,' implying not arbitrary authority, but gentle, though faithful, admonition.
Albert Barnes: The word ‘know’ seems to mean that they were not to make themselves strangers to them - to be cold and distant toward them - to be ignorant of their needs, or to be indifferent to them.
They should so far understand his circumstances as to know what is requisite to make him comfortable, and should be on such terms that they may readily and cheerfully furnish what he needs.
It is a part of the duty of a minister to put his people in mind of the truth; to warn them of danger; to exhort them to perform their duty; to admonish them if they go astray.
Marvin Vincent: Recognize them for what they are, and as entitled to respect because of their office.
The ecclesiastical nomenclature of the Pauline Epistles is unsettled, corresponding with the fact that the primitive church was not a homogeneous body throughout christendom.
The recognition of those who ministered to the congregations depended on the free choice of their members.
John Calvin: We must observe, however, with what titles of distinction he honors pastors...Farther, he expresses the kind of labor when he adds, those that admonish, or instruct, you. It is to no purpose, therefore, that any, that do not discharge the office of an instructor, glory in the name of pastors.

Paul would have such as devote themselves to teaching, and preside with no other end in view than that of serving the Church, be held in no ordinary esteem...we must observe the reason that he adds immediately afterwards — on account of their work. Now, this work is the edification of the Church, the everlasting salvation of souls, the restoration of the world, and, in fine, the kingdom of God and Christ.

For he says literally — let them be more than abundantly honored, and not without good ground, for we must observe the reason that he adds immediately afterwards — on account of their work. Now, this work is the edification of the Church, the everlasting salvation of souls, the restoration of the world, and, in fine, the kingdom of God and Christ.
Philip Schaff: To know. ‘That is, to appreciate, not to be unaware of their real work’ (Vaughan)."
Those who labour among you, and preside over you and admonish you. All three functions belong to the same office."
Ruling and teaching were the two grand divisions of ecclesiastical labour.
Archibald T. Robertson: Them that labour among you (τους κοπιωντας εν υμιν). Old word for toil even if weary.

And are over you in the Lord (κα προισταμενους υμων εν Κυριω). Same article with this participle. Literally, those who stand in front of you, your leaders in the Lord, the presbyters or bishops and deacons. Get acquainted with them and follow them.

And admonish you (κα νουθετουντας υμας). Old verb from νουθετης and this from νους (mind) and τιθημ, to put. Putting sense into the heads of people. A thankless, but a necessary, task. The same article connects all three participles, different functions of the same leaders in the church.
John Gill: They laboured in the word and doctrine; gave up themselves to meditation, reading, and prayer; laboured hard in private, to find out the meaning of the word of God; and studied to show themselves workmen, that need not be ashamed; and preached the word in season and out of season."
They laboured to enlighten their understandings, to inform their judgments, to raise their affections, and to bring their wills to a resignation to the will of God."
They were made able ministers of the word by God; received their gifts qualifying them for this work from Christ, and were placed as overseers of the church by the Holy Ghost.
John Wesley: Know — See, mark, take knowledge of them and their work.
Sometimes the same person may both labour, that is, preach; be over, or govern; and admonish the flock by particular application to each.
But O, what a misery is it when a man undertakes this whole work without either gifts or graces for any part of it!

bhtAttempts.bht: Recognize the favorably and honorably work of the presbyters or bishops who labor among you, preside over you, and admonish you in the Lord. Appreciate their office and treat them with respect and generosity. It is their duty to remind and instruct you in the truth, warn of danger, and exhort you to fulfill your responsibilities. The ecclesiastical nomenclature may vary in different churches, but the recognition of their ministry depends on the free choice of their members. They are called to toil, lead, and put sense into the heads of the congregation. Let them be abundantly honored for their work in the edification of the Church and the everlasting salvation of souls. These laborers in the word and doctrine dedicate themselves to studying, meditating, praying, and preaching the word, aiming to enlighten, inform, and align the hearts and minds of the people with God's will. Their ministry is grounded in the grace and gifts received from God, and they have been appointed as overseers by the Holy Spirit. Take knowledge of them and their work, but be cautious not to undertake the whole work without the necessary gifts and graces.

Recognize and honor the presbyters or bishops who labor among you, preside over you, and admonish you in the Lord. Appreciate their office and treat them with respect and generosity. It is their duty to instruct you in the truth, warn of danger, and exhort you to fulfill your responsibilities. Let them be abundantly honored for their work in the edification of the Church and the everlasting salvation of souls. These laborers in the word and doctrine dedicate themselves to preaching, studying, meditating, and praying, aiming to enlighten and align the hearts and minds of the people with God's will.

Recognize and honor the presbyters or bishops who labor among you, preside over you, and admonish you in the Lord. Appreciate their office, treat them with respect, and generously support their needs. They are called to put sense into the heads of the congregation, gently reminding and instructing them. Let these laborers in the word be abundantly honored for their work in the edification of the Church and the salvation of souls. They diligently study, pray, and preach to enlighten and align the hearts and minds of the people with God's will.

Recognize and honor the presbyters or bishops who labor among you, preside over you, and admonish you in the Lord. Appreciate their office, treat them with respect, and generously support their needs. These laborers dedicate themselves to preaching, studying, meditating, and praying, aiming to enlighten and align the hearts and minds of the people with God's will. Let them be abundantly honored for their work in the edification of the Church and the salvation of souls. Their ministry is grounded in the grace and gifts received from God, and they have been appointed as overseers by the Holy Spirit.

Recognize and honor the presbyters or bishops among you, who work diligently, preside over you, and gently admonish you in divine matters. Treat them with respect and generously support their needs. These laborers dedicate themselves to preaching, studying, praying, and putting sense into the heads of the congregation. Let them be abundantly honored for their work in the spiritual growth of the Church and the salvation of souls. Their ministry is grounded in the grace and gifts received from God, and they have been appointed as overseers by the Holy Spirit.
